titleStmt.title: His Maiesties answer to a message sent to him by the House of Commons, at Yorke, March 19. 1641. Also two remarkable letters from Ireland sent over by Robert Pickering, secretary unto Sir Symon Harcourt, March, 17. 1641. The first being the copy of a letter written by the Earle of Osmond one of the commanders of the rebels, unto the Earle of Delvin, wherein he declares the great distresse they are in for want of ammunition and other provision, and also frustrate of the reliefe they hoped for out of Flanders. Which letter and bearer was intercepted by the night scouts of Sir Symon Harcourt. The second, the copie of the Popes Bull sent unto the Irish rebels, found in the trunke of Macke Orobie, his legate, who was taken prisoner in the Lord Mountgarrets quarter.
titleStmt.author: England and Wales. Sovereign (1625-1649 : Charles I)

The second, the copie of the Popes Bull sent unto the Irish rebels, found in the trunke of Macke Orobie, his legate, who was taken prisoner in the Lord Mountgarrets quarter.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: His Maie≈øties An≈øwer to a Me≈ø≈øage ≈øent to him by the Hou≈øe of Commons, at Yorke, March 19. 1641.
ALSO Two Remarkable Letters from IRELAND Sent over by Robert Pickering, Secretary unto Sir Symon Harcourt, March, 17. 1641.

The fir≈øt being the Copy of a Letter written by the Earle of O≈ømond one of the Commanders of the Rebels, unto the Earle of Delvin, wherein he declares the great di≈øtre≈ø≈øe they are in for want of Ammunition and other Provi≈øion, and al≈øo fru≈øtrate of the reliefe they hoped for out of Flanders.
Which Letter and Bearer was intercepted by the night Scouts of Sir Symon Harcourt.
The ≈øecond, the Copie of the Popes Bull ≈øent unto the Iri≈øh Rebels, found in the Trunke of Macke Orobie, his Legate, who was taken pri≈øoner in the Lord Mountgarrets Quarter.

div.head: The Copie of a Letter written by the Earle of O≈ømond a Commander of the Rebels, unto the Earle of Delvia, that lay at the Head of Hoare.
div.p:
I Wi≈øh J could ≈øalute you with better Newes, or you ≈øerved me with better Councell, when it would have ≈øtood me in ≈øtead; J give us all for undone, onely this choice as yet is left us, that wee may choo≈øe the Sword before the Halter, Tom Butler writes from Bru≈ø≈øels: That the Spaniard loves us well, but him≈øelfe a great deale better: I he Governout of Flanders hath made ≈øtay of the Ships in Dunkirke, norwith≈øtanding the meanes he made to his Confe≈ø≈øor, who laboured by all Jmportunity to get the Ammunition free, if not the bottomes, but could obtain nothing we then deale effectually with the Governour and Captaine of Dunkirke by the Sollicitation of the Iri≈øh Cloi≈øter, to let them ≈øteate away as if it were unknowne to them, but neither would heare him. The Count from Bru≈ø≈øels had beene a≈øore him, and had layd ≈øuch a ≈øtrict charge upon him, that
he would li≈øten to nothing: The King of Spaine in this ca≈øe, his rea≈øon is ≈øetcht from Portugall, that none of the Engli≈øh may helpe again≈øt him. he with holds his wonted ayd to us, but the Engli≈øh will as certainly deceive him, when their owne turne is ≈øerved and they have made an end with us: The Spaniard will find more Engli≈øh in Portugall then he will be willing to bid welcome, they hate him as cordially as us, and us the more for the Re≈øpect bore us from Spaine.
More Forces are arrived from England, 400 vnder the command of one Greenvill, with 700 more, the Scots are of a certaine arrived in the North al≈øo, but what number yet J cannot learne.
It is Rumoured in Dublin, that now the Parliament in England will pre≈ø≈øe a great Army for Leice≈øter, and that he will be here before Ea≈øter.

We are likely to bee be≈øet on all ≈øides, and for ought I ≈øee to be devoured, Roach is Arrived out of France, but with as little comfort, The Cardinall giveth good words, but wee may ju≈øtly ≈øu≈øpect his performance.

The French King is ≈øo imbarked in the Spani≈øh Broyle, that he I feare will little heed vs, my men begin to be weary of it already, The ≈øame Philomy writes of his, And ≈øo it will follow in others, For we are naked of Armes, And e≈øpecially de≈øtitute of powder, The taking of that provi≈øion at Eniskenning hath lo≈øt vs both our Lives and Honour, Let me de≈øire you, at your fir≈øt conveniencie, to ≈øend my Wife and Three Daughters for Nantes, or Dunkirke, And for my part, if friends abroad regard neither the Common tye of the Catholique Faith; Not their former promi≈øes, But onely their owne particulers: As we have but too ju≈øt cau≈øe to doubt they doe not, J will ≈øhortly over too, leaving all to the Arbitrament of Fortune, Rather then to ≈øee the mi≈øerable ≈ølavery of my Nation, And utter treading
downe of my Countrey by the Barbarous morelle≈ø≈øe Scots, and proud in≈øulting Engli≈øh; If you have any better Tydings to write, You may Commit them to the bearer ≈øafely, Macke me Cherrie, Who by rea≈øon of his perfect Engli≈øh Tongue, pa≈ø≈øeth for one of that Nation; And thereby ≈øometime doth advantage vs; My Love Commend vnto my Carefull Counte≈ø≈øe and Young Daughter; Thus Committing your and our affayres to the Almighty, and protection of Saint PATRICKE.

div.head: The Coppie of the Popes Bull unto the Iri≈øh Rebels.
div.p: VRBAN the eyght, by the Divine providence, Bi≈øhop of Rome. Bi≈øhop of Bi≈øhops, and ≈øervant of the ≈øervant of God. To all the Cleargie, Peeres, and people of Jreland, his well beloved Sonnes in Chri≈øt, now con≈øederate in holy League, for the maintenance of Catholique Religion to the very perill of their blood, greeting and Apo≈øtolicall benediction.

SEeing that your un≈øpeakeable ≈øufferings have beene now of late related unto us, by the Provo≈øt of the Iri≈øh Nation, of late which yee have undergone for the≈øe many Ages, not onely patiently, but willingly groaning under the Egyptian Yoake of Hete≈øie, more heavie then that of Pharoahs, yea and mo≈øt ready to beare it ≈øtill, ≈øo that, the one thing nece≈ø≈øary, the mo≈øt unvaluable Pearle, the better part might not hee taken from you, nor the gate of Eternall happine≈ø≈øe after Life ended ≈øhut again≈øt you. Which when wee under≈øtood, Wee as our dutie required, with bended Knee both of heart and bodie, have recommended this your mo≈øt pious intention to the Throne of grace, at the ble≈ø≈øed Sacrifice of the Altar, feare yee not that ever ayde cele≈øtiall ≈øhall be wanting to you, who have ≈øo religiou≈øly preferred the ≈øalvation of your Souls, Chri≈øts Spou≈øe, the welfare of the Church Catholque, before your lively hoods and honours, freinds, Fathers, Mothers, Wives, Children, Sonnes, Daughters, Yea, and then which nothing is more deare to man, life it ≈øelfe, how ≈øhall the Saviour of the World pa≈ø≈øe by you di≈øregarded, whom in his Go≈øpell he ≈øolemnely profe≈ø≈øeth to be more deare unto him then his owne Bretheren ≈øhall not Chri≈øt
fight for his owne Champions, will not ble≈ø≈øed St. Peter maintaine them that weigh not their owne po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, ≈øo they may de≈øend his, God forbid that you ≈øhould ever be de≈øtitute of a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, who have the ble≈ø≈øed Mother of God for their ≈øhield and Buckler, as whom they honour, reverence, and adore, more zealou≈øly then all the World, goe on with pro≈øperous ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, behave your ≈øelves manfully, that which yee have with tran≈øcendant piety begun, Wee earne≈øtly require that with re≈øolved con≈øtancy yee endeavour to accompli≈øh, ≈øtrictly charging you that you by no meanes ye withdraw your hand from this plough, lea≈øt yee be ever after unfit for the glorious ≈øociety of heavenly trumphant Catholiques, you ≈øhall not onely have the univer≈øall party of the Roman Catholique faith ≈øpectators, but Orators and fuitors to the divine Deity in heaven but coadjutors, contributors to their utmo≈øt power in wi≈øhes con≈øultations, allowances both for Armes, Victuals and other things nece≈ø≈øary there in your Country & of this be a≈ø≈øured, as for us to whom the government of our Lords ble≈ø≈øed ve≈ø≈øell is committed, doubt yee not but that you ≈øhall continually have us an interce≈ø≈øor to the Court of heaven for you, and an advances of your ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, and enterprize there in your Kingdome, all the wayes wee for our Pa≈øtorall dutie ≈øhall thinke meete≈øt: What remaineth, Wee by this our Legate Orobie with the ≈øumme of Foure hundred Duckets; with hearty recommendation and pa≈øtorall affection be≈øtow upon you our plenarie Judulgence of all your ≈øinnes, and benediction Apo≈øtolicall.

closer.dateline: Given at Rome the la≈øt of February New-≈øtile, Anno Salutis 1642. Under the Seale of the Fi≈øherman, in the Nineteenth yeare of our Popedome.

argument.p: Under written, Rancone and S. R. L. P. S.

div.head: His Maje≈øties An≈øwer to a Me≈ø≈øage ≈øent to Him by the Hou≈øe of Commons, concerning Lycences granted by him to per≈øons to goe into Ireland.
div.p: HIS Maje≈øty hath ≈øeen and con≈øidered the Me≈ø≈øage pre≈øented to Him by the Lord: Compton and Ma≈øter Baynton, the 19th of March, 1641. at Yorke; Touching ≈øuch per≈øons as have been Licen≈øed by His Maje≈øty to pa≈ø≈øe into Ireland.

Though he will not in≈øi≈øt upon what little Rea≈øon they had to ≈øu≈øpect that ≈øome ill-affected per≈øons had pa≈ø≈øed into Ireland, under colour of his Maje≈øties Licence (Inferences being ≈ølender Proofes to ground beliefe upon) yet he mu≈øt needs avow, That for any thing that is yet Declared, He cannot ≈øee any ground why Ma≈øter Pym ≈øhould ≈øo boldly affirme before both hou≈øes of Parliament, I hat ≈øince the ≈øtop upon the Ports by both Hou≈øes again≈øt all Iri≈øh Papi≈øts, many of the chiefe Commanders now in the head of the Rebells, have been ≈øuffered to pa≈ø≈øe by his Maje≈øties immediate VVarant; For as yet there is not any particular per≈øon named that is now ≈øo much as in Rebellion (much le≈ø≈øe in the head of the Rebells) to whom his Maje≈øty hath given Licence.

And therefore according to his Maje≈øties Reply upon that Subject, His Maje≈øtie expects, That his Hou≈øe of Commons publi≈øh ≈øuch a Declaration, Whereby this mi≈øtaking may be cleared, That ≈øo all the World may ≈øee his Maje≈øties Caution in giving of Pa≈ø≈øes; And likewi≈øe, That his Mini≈øters have not abu≈øed his Maje≈øties tru≈øt, by any ≈øurreptitious Warrants.

And la≈øtly, his Ma ‚Ä¢ e≈øty expects, That hen ‚Ä¢ eforth there be more warine ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e u≈øed, before ≈øuch publike A≈øper≈øions be laid; unle≈ø≈øe the Grounds be before-hand better Warranted by ≈øufficient Proofes.
